It sounds like you're looking to incorporate swimming into your fitness routine in addition to continuing your running. That's a great way to cross-train and reduce the risk of overuse injuries.

Here's a sample 4-day workout plan that you can follow for the next few weeks, incorporating both running and swimming:

**Monday (Running Day)**

* Warm-up: 10-15 minutes of easy jogging or walking
* 30-40 minutes of steady-state running at a moderate pace
* Cool-down: 10-15 minutes of stretching

**Tuesday (Swimming Day)**

* Warm-up: 5-10 minutes of easy swimming (freestyle or breaststroke)
* Focus on technique drills for 20-30 minutes (e.g., kick sets, arm circles, flip turns)
* Endurance swim: 10-20 minutes of steady swimming at a moderate pace
* Cool-down: 5-10 minutes of stretching

**Thursday (Running Day)**

* Warm-up: 10-15 minutes of easy jogging or walking
* Interval training: 20-30 minutes of alternating between fast and slow running (e.g., 4-6 x 400m at a fast pace, with 200m active recovery in between)
* Cool-down: 10-15 minutes of stretching

**Saturday (Swimming Day)**

* Warm-up: 5-10 minutes of easy swimming (freestyle or breaststroke)
* Endurance swim: 20-30 minutes of steady swimming at a moderate pace
* Focus on technique drills for 10-20 minutes (e.g., kicking with a kickboard, arm strokes with a pull buoy)
* Cool-down: 5-10 minutes of stretching

Remember to listen to your body and adjust the intensity and duration of your workouts based on how you're feeling. It's also important to include rest days or active recovery days (e.g., yoga, cycling, or light walking) to allow your body to recover and adapt to the new demands you're placing on it.

How does this sample workout plan sound? Are there any changes you'd like to make or any specific goals you'd like to focus on in the next few weeks?
